1.1: In the Sinai desert, the Lord spoke to Moses inside the Tent of Meeting on the first day of the second month of the second year after they had left the land of Egypt. He said,
1.2: “Take a census of the entire Israeli community, numbering them by their tribes and by ancestral houses. List the names of every male one-by-one,
1.3: from 20 years and upward. You and Aaron are to register everyone in Israel who is able to go to war, company by company.
1.4: One man from each tribe is to accompany you, each man being the leader of his ancestral house.
1.5:
“Here is a list of names of the men who are to assist you:
“From Reuben: Shedeur’s son Elizur.
1.10: “From Joseph’s descendants through Ephraim: Ammihud’s son Elishama. From Manasseh: Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel.
1.16: These men were appointed from within their communities, since they were leaders of their ancestral houses and heads of the tribes of Israel.
1.17: Moses and Aaron gathered these men who had been mentioned by name.
1.18: They assembled the entire community together during the second month. Then they recorded their ancestries, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as well as the names of the men 20 years old and above individually,
1.19: just as the Lord had commanded Moses. He numbered them in the Sinai desert.
1.20: The genealogies of the descendants of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.21: Those registered with the tribe of Reuben numbered 46,500.
1.22: The genealogies of Simeon’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.23: Those registered with the tribe of Simeon numbered 59,300.
1.24: The genealogies of Gad’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.25: Those registered with the tribe of Gad numbered 45,650.
1.26: The genealogies of Judah’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.27: Those registered with the tribe of Judah numbered 74,600.
1.28: The genealogies of Issachar’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.29: Those registered with the tribe of Issachar numbered 54,400.
1.30: The genealogies of Zebulun’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.31: Those registered with the tribe of Zebulun numbered 57,400.
1.32: The genealogies of Joseph’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.33: Those registered with the tribe of Joseph numbered 40,500.
1.34: The genealogies of Manasseh’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.35: Those registered with the tribe of Manasseh numbered 32,200.
1.36: The genealogies of Benjamin’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.37: Those registered with the tribe of Benjamin numbered 35,400.
1.38: The genealogies of Dan’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.39: Those registered with the tribe of Dan numbered 62,700.
1.40: The genealogies of Asher’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.41: Those registered with the tribe of Asher numbered 41,500.
1.42: The genealogies of Naphtali’s descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.43: Those registered with the family of Naphtali numbered 53,400.
1.44: These individuals were the ones whom Moses and Aaron registered from the twelve leaders of Israel, each person from his ancestral house.
1.45: Everyone was numbered from the descendants of Israel, from their ancestral houses, from all the men who were 20 years and above and who could serve in the army.
1.46: The total of all those who were numbered was 603,550.
1.47: The descendants of Levi were not counted according to their ancestral houses
1.48: because the Lord had ordered Moses:
1.49: “Be sure not to number or count the tribe of Levi with the rest of the Israelis.
1.50: Instead, appoint the descendants of Levi over the Tent of Meeting, all the vessels, and everything in it. They are to carry the tent and all the vessels in it. They are to attend to it and camp around it.
1.51: Whenever the tent is ready for travel, the descendants of Levi are to take it down. When it’s time to encamp, the descendants of Levi are to set it up. Any unauthorized person who approaches it is to be executed.
1.52: Then the Israelis are to encamp around the tent, arranged according to their company and the standard of their army.
1.53: But the descendants of Levi are to encamp on all sides of the Tent of Meeting so that divine wrath won’t fall on the congregation of Israel. The descendants of Levi are to take care of the Tent of Meeting.”
1.54: The Israelis observed everything that the Lord had commanded Moses, doing exactly what they were told.

2.1: Later, the Lord told Moses and Aaron,
2.2: “Every single Israeli is to encamp beneath his standard with the emblem of his ancestral house. The Israelis are to encamp in front of and surrounding the Tent of Meeting.”
2.3: “The encampment of Judah is to settle east toward the sunrise under their standard. The leader of Judah is to be Amminadab’s son Nahshon.
2.5: “The tribe of Issachar is to encamp beside Judah. The leader of Issachar is to be Zuar’s son Nethanel.
2.7: “Next is to be the tribe of Zebulun. The leader of Zebulun is to be Helon’s son Eliab.
2.9: All those numbered by division in the camp of Judah total 186,400. They are to be the first to travel.”
2.10: “Toward the south is to be the division of the camp of Reuben under their standard. The leader of Reuben is to be Shedeur’s son Elizur.
2.12: “The tribe of Simeon is to camp beside Reuben. The leader of Simeon is to be Zurishaddai’s son Shelumiel.
2.14: “Next is to be the tribe of Gad. The leader of Gad is to be Deuel’s son Eliasaph.
2.16: All those numbered by division in the camp of Reuben total 151,450. They are to be the second to travel.”
2.17: “Then the Tent of Meeting is to travel with the camp of the descendants of Levi in the middle of the camps. They are to travel just as they have camped, each as designated under his standard.”
2.18: “Toward the west is to be the division of the camp of Ephraim under their standard. The leader of Ephraim is to be Ammihud’s son Elishama.
2.20: “The tribe of Manasseh is to encamp beside them. The leader of Manasseh is to be Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel.
2.22: “Next is to be the tribe of Benjamin. The leader of Benjamin is to be Gideoni’s son Abidan.
2.24: All those numbered by division in the camp Ephraim total 108,100. They are to be the third to travel.”
2.25: “Toward the north is to be the division of the camp of Dan under their standard. The leader of Dan is to be Ammishaddai’s son Ahiezer.
2.27: “The tribe of Asher is to encamp beside them. The leader of Asher is to be Ochran’s son Pagiel.
2.29: “Next is to be the tribe of Naphtali. The leader of Naphtali is to be Enan’s son Ahira.
2.31: All those numbered by division in the camp of Dan total 157,600. They are to be the last to travel under their standards.”
2.32: Here is a summary of the census of the Israelis according to the tribes of their ancestral houses: All the divisions in the camps numbered 603,550,
2.33: but the descendants of Levi were not numbered along with the other Israelis, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
2.34: So the Israelis did everything just as the Lord had commanded Moses; that is, they encamped under their standard as each person traveled with his own tribe and ancestral house.

3.1: This is a record of the genealogies of Aaron and Moses current as of the day on which the Lord addressed Moses on Mount Sinai.
3.2: The sons of Aaron were Nadab the first-born, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar
3.3: who were anointed priests and whom he consecrated as priests.
3.4: Nadab and Abihu died in the Lord’s presence when they offered unauthorized fire before him in the Sinai wilderness. Since they didn’t have their own children, Eleazar and Ithamar ministered as priests under the authority of Aaron their father.
3.6: “Bring the tribe of Levi near and present them to Aaron the priest so they may serve him.
3.7: They are to take care of his needs and the needs of the whole congregation at the Tent of Meeting by performing duties at the tent.
3.8: They are to take charge of the utensils at the Tent of Meeting and meet the needs of the Israelis by performing duties on behalf of the tent.
3.9: Assign the descendants of Levi to Aaron and his sons from among the Israelis.
3.10: Appoint Aaron and his sons so that they are to take responsibility for their priesthood. Any unauthorized person who approaches it is to be put to death.”
3.12: “I’m taking the descendants of Levi for myself from among the Israelis in place of every first-born who opens the womb. The descendants of Levi belong to me
3.13: because all the first-born belong to me. When I destroyed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, I consecrated all the first-born in Israel for myself—from human beings to livestock. They belong to me, since I am the Lord.”
3.14: The Lord also told Moses in the Sinai wilderness,
3.15: “Number the descendants of Levi according to their ancestral houses and tribes, numbering every male from a month old and above.”
3.16: So Moses numbered them according to the instruction of the Lord, as he had been commanded.
3.17: These are Levi’s descendants by name: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
3.18: These are names of Gershon’s descendants according to their families: Libni and Shimei.
3.19: These are the names of Kohath’s descendants according to their families: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
3.20: Merari’s descendants according to their families were Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the descendants of Levi according to their ancestral house.
3.21: The families of Libni and Shimei were descendants of Gershon. As families of the descendants of Gershon,
3.22: all the males a month old and above numbered 7,500.
3.23: The families of the descendants of Gershon encamped behind the tent toward the west.
3.24: The leader of the tribe and family of Gershon was Lael’s son Eliasaph.
3.25: The duties of the descendants of Gershon at the Tent of Meeting pertained to the tent, the tent covering, the curtain to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting,
3.26: the hangings at the courtyard, the curtain at the entrance of the courtyard that surrounded the tent, the altar, and all of the tent cords in use.
3.27: The families of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel were descendants of Kohath. As families of the descendants of Kohath,
3.28: all the males a month old and above numbered 8,600. They were tasked to the care of the sanctuary.
3.29: The descendants of Kohath encamped beside the tent toward the south.
3.30: The leader of the tribe and family of Kohath was Uzziel’s son Elizaphan.
3.31: Their duties pertained to the ark, the table, the lamp stand, the altars, the utensils of the sanctuary with which they ministered, and all the curtains in use.
3.32: The chief of all the leaders of the descendants of Levi was Aaron the priest’s son Eleazar. He was assigned to oversee those who were in charge of the services of the sanctuary.
3.33: The families of Mahli and Mushi were descendants of Merari. As families of Merari,
3.34: all the males a month old and above numbered 6,200.
3.35: The leader of the tribe and family of Merari was Abihail’s son Zuriel. The descendants of Merari encamped beside the tent toward the north.
3.36: The duties of the caretakers from the descendants of Merari included the boards of the tent, its bars, crossbars, sockets, all its utensils for their services,
3.37: the pillars around the courtyard, their sockets, pegs, and tent cords.
3.38: In front of the tent and east of the Tent of Meeting, Moses, Aaron, and Aaron’s sons encamped facing the east. They were tasked to perform the duties of the sanctuary and care for the needs of the Israelis. Any unauthorized person who approached was to be executed.
3.39: As the Lord had instructed, everyone counted by Moses and Aaron from the descendants of Levi, according to their tribe, all males from a month old and above numbered 22,000.
3.40: Later the Lord instructed Moses: “Number all the first-born males of Israel from a month old and above and list their names.
3.41: Separate the descendants of Levi for me—since I am the Lord—in place of all the first-born sons of Israel. Also separate the livestock of the descendants of Levi in place of all the firstborn of the livestock of Israel.”
3.42: So Moses numbered all the firstborn from the sons of Israel just as the Lord commanded him.
3.43: All the first-born males according to the list of their names from a month old and above numbered 22,273.
3.45: “Separate the descendants of Levi in place of all the firstborn sons of Israel and the livestock of the descendants of Levi in place of their livestock. The descendants of Levi belong to me, since I am the Lord.
3.46: You are to pay a ransom for the 273 first-born Israelis who exceed the census number of the descendants of Levi,
3.47: so collect five shekels for each individual, denominated in shekels of the sanctuary, that is, the shekel that weighs 20 gerahs.
3.48: Then give the money meant for ransom of their excess to Aaron and his sons.”
3.49: So Moses took the ransom money to account for the difference in the total number of those redeemed by the descendants of Levi.
3.50: From the firstborn of the Israelis, Moses took money amounting to 1,365 shekels according to the shekel of the sanctuary.
3.51: Moses gave the ransom money to Aaron and his sons according to the Lord’s instructions, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

4.1: The Lord told Moses and Aaron,
4.2: “Take a census of the descendants of Kohath from among the descendants of Levi according to their tribes and ancestral houses
4.3: from 30 years and older through the age of 50 years, from everyone who can enter the service to perform work at the Tent of Meeting.
4.4: “Here’s what the descendants of Kohath are to do regarding the Tent of Meeting and what’s inside the Most Holy Place:
4.5: When the camp is about to travel, Aaron and his sons are to come and take down the veil of the curtain and cover the Ark of the Testimony with it.
4.6: They are to set a leather-dyed skin covering over it, cover it with a pure blue cloth, and then insert its poles.
4.7: “They are to spread a blue cloth over the table of the Presence and on top of it the dishes, pans, bowls, pitchers for drink offerings, and the bread of presence are to be on it continually.
4.8: They are to spread over them a scarlet cloth and a leather-dyed skin covering and then insert its poles.
4.9: “They are to take a blue cloth and cover the lamp stand for the light with its lamp, lamp-snuffers, censer, and all the utensils for its oil with which they minister.
4.10: Then they are to put them with all the other utensils on the leather-dyed skin covering and set them on the beams for transport.
4.11: “On the golden altar, they are to spread a blue cloth, cover it with a leather-dyed skin covering, and then insert its poles.
4.12: Then they are to take all the utensils for service with which they minister at the sanctuary, set them on the blue cloth, cover them with the leather-dyed skin covering, and then set them on the beams for transport.
4.13: They are also to remove the ashes on the altar and spread a purple cloth over it.
4.14: Then they are to put all the instruments with which they minister there—trays, forks, shovels, bowls, and all the utensils of the altar. They are to spread over it a leather-dyed skin covering and then insert its poles.
4.15: “When Aaron and his sons have finished covering the sanctuary and all the utensils of the sanctuary, and the camp is about to travel, then the descendants of Kohath are to come and carry them, but they are not to touch the most sacred objects, so they won’t die. These are the duties of the descendants of Kohath at the Tent of Meeting.”
4.16: “Now the duty of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest is to maintain the oil for the light, the spiced incense, the daily offerings, andthe oil for anointing, to carry out all the duties of the tent and the sanctuary, and to maintain its utensils.”
4.17: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron,
4.18: “You are not to eliminate the tribe of the families of the descendants of Kohath from the descendants of Levi.
4.19: But do this for them so that they may live and not die when they approach the Most Holy Place: Aaron and his sons are to go in and set specific responsibilities for each of them to carry out.
4.20: But they are not to go in to see the sanctuary as it is being covered, so they won’t die.”
4.22: “Take a census of the descendants of Gershon according to their ancestral house and tribes.
4.23: Count their number from between 30 to 50 years old, including everyone who can enter the service to perform work at the Tent of Meeting.”
4.24: “These are the responsibilities that the descendants of Gershon are to have:
4.25: They are to carry the curtain of the tent, the covering of the Tent of Meeting, the dyed leather covering that goes over it, the curtain for the entrance to the Tent of Meeting,
4.26: the hangings for the courtyard, the curtain for the entrance to the gate of the courtyard that surrounds the tent, the altar, the ropes, all the service utensils, and everything made for them. This is to be their service area.
4.27: The descendants of Gershon are to carry out the instructions of Aaron and his sons. You are to assign them their responsibilities to carry out.
4.28: This is the work of the tribes of Gershon at the Tent of Meeting—their duties under the supervision of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
4.29: “For the descendants of Merari, number them according to their tribes and ancestral houses
4.30: from 30 to 50 years old as you count them, including everyone who can enter service and perform work at the Tent of Meeting.
4.31: This is to be their area of responsibility to carry out with respect to their service at the Tent of Meeting: the board of the tent, its bars, its crossbars, its sockets,
4.32: the pillars around the courtyard, their sockets, their pegs, their ropes, and all the utensils for all their services. Assign the utensils by name to each person whose responsibility it will be to carry them.
4.33: This is the work of the tribes of the descendants of Merari with reference to their service at the Tent of Meeting under the supervision of Aaron the priest’s son Ithamar.”
4.34: Moses, Aaron, and the congregational leaders numbered the descendants of Kohath according to their tribes and ancestral houses
4.35: from 30 to 50 years old—that is, everyone who entered the service to perform work at the Tent of Meeting.
4.36: The total according to their tribe numbered 2,750
4.37: from the tribe of the descendants of Kohath, everyone who would be serving at the Tent of Meeting, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to what the Lord had said, under the supervision of Moses.
4.38: The tribes and the ancestral houses of the descendants of Gershon were numbered
4.39: from 30 to 50 years old; that is, everyone who entered the service to perform work at the Tent of Meeting.
4.40: The total according to their tribes and ancestral house numbered 2,630
4.41: from the tribes of the descendants of Gershon, everyone who would be serving at the Tent of Meeting, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to what the Lord had said.
4.42: The tribes and ancestral house of Merari were numbered
4.43: from 30 to 50 years old; that is, everyone who entered the service to perform work at the Tent of Meeting.
4.44: The total according to their tribes numbered 3,200
4.45: from the tribes of the descendants of Merari, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to what the Lord had said, under the supervision of Moses.
4.46: The total of those who were numbered from the descendants of Levi by Moses and Aaron; that is, from the leaders of Israel counted according to their tribes and ancestral houses
4.47: from 30 to 50 years old, who entered the service for work at the Tent of Meeting
4.49: They were numbered under the supervision of Moses according to what the Lord had said. Each person was assigned a responsibility to carry out, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

5.2: “Command the Israelis to send outside the encampment every leper, everyone who has a discharge, and whoever is ritually defiled by contact with a corpse.
5.3: Whether male or female, send them outside the camp so that they won’t defile their camp, because I live among them.”
5.4: So the Israelis sent them outside the camp. The Israelis did just what the Lord had told Moses.
5.6: “Instruct the Israelis that whenever a man or woman does something contained in the list of the sins of man, thereby acting treacherously against the Lord, then that person stands guilty.
5.7: He is to confess the sin that he had committed, pay its full compensation, add one fifth to it, and give the compensation to whomever he offended.
5.8: But if the person has no related redeemer to whom compensation may be made, the payment is to be brought to the Lord and given to the priest, in addition to a ram for atonement with which he is to be atoned.
5.9: Every offering from all the most sacred things of the Israelis that they bring to the priest is to belong to him.
5.10: Furthermore, everyone’s sacred things belong to him, as well as whatever a person gives to the priest.”
5.12: “Instruct the Israelis what to do if a man’s wife turns astray so that she unfaithfully acts against him,
5.13: a man has sexual relations with her and she conceals it from her husband, keeping it secret although she has defiled herself with there being no witnesses against her, but she was caught anyway.
5.14: If an attitude of jealousy overcomes him so that he becomes jealous at his wife when she is defiled, or if an attitude of jealousy overcomes him and he becomes jealous of his wife even though she isn’t defiled,
5.15: then that man is to bring his wife to the priest along with an offering for her consisting of a tenth of an ephah of barley flour. He is not to pour oil or set frankincense over it, because it’s to be a jealousy offering, a memorial offering that will serve as a reminder of iniquity.
5.16: Then the priest is to bring it and make her stand in the Lord’s presence.
5.17: The priest is to put some holy water into an earthen vessel, take some dust from the floor of the tent, and put it into the water.
5.18: The priest is to have the woman stand in the Lord’s presence, uncover her head, and put the grain offering as a memorial, a reminder of jealousy, into her hands. The priest is also to have in his hand the contaminated water that carries a curse.
5.19: “The priest is to administer this oath to the woman: ‘If indeed another man didn’t have sexual relations with you and you didn’t become unfaithful to your husband, then may you be free from these waters that bring a curse.
5.20: But if you have become unfaithful to your husband and have become defiled because a man who isn’t your husband has had sexual relations with you…’
5.21: then the priest is to have the woman commit to an oath by saying to the woman, ‘May the Lord make you a curse and a curse among your people. When the Lord makes your thigh waste away and your abdomen swell
5.22:
and this water that brings a curse enters your abdomen, making it swell and your thigh waste away.’
“Then the woman is to say ‘Amen.’
5.23: “Then the priest is to write all of these words in a document and wipe it off with the contaminated water.
5.24: The woman is to drink the bitter water that brings a curse and the water that brings a curse is to be considered contaminated.
5.25: The priest is to take the offering of jealousy from the woman’s hand, wave the offering in the Lord’s presence, and have her approach the altar.
5.26: The priest is to take a handful of grain from the memorial and offer a sacrifice on the altar, after which he is to have the woman drink the water.
5.27: When he has had her drink the water, if she was defiled and had acted unfaithfully toward her husband, then the contaminated water that brings a curse will enter her and infect her, causing her abdomen to swell and her thigh to waste away. Then she is to be a cursed woman among her people.
5.28: But if the woman isn’t defiled, then she is to be freed and will be able to bear children.
5.29: This is the law in cases of jealousy when a woman defiles herself while under her husband’s authority:
5.30: When a man becomes under the control of an attitude of jealousy regarding his wife, he is to present her to the Lord, and the priest is to apply this entire statute to her.
5.31: The husband will be free from guilt, but the wife is to bear the punishment of her iniquity.”

6.2: “Tell the Israelis that a man or woman who commits to the vow of the Nazirite, is to be separated to the Lord,
6.3: then is to remain separate from wine and strong drink. He is not to drink vinegar or strong drink made from wine. He is not to drink grape juice or eat grapes, whether fresh or dried.
6.4: During the entire time of his dedication, he is not to eat any product from the grapevine, from the seed to the skin.
6.5: During the entire time of his dedication, he is not to allow a razor to pass over his head until the days of his holy consecration to the Lord have been fulfilled. He is to let the locks on his head grow long.
6.6: “During the entire time of his dedication, he is not to come near a dead body.
6.7: He is not to defile himself on account of his father, mother, brother, and sister when they die, because the crown of his consecration to God is on his head.
6.8: During the entire time of his dedication, he is set apart to God.
6.9: When someone suddenly dies beside him, so that his consecrated head is defiled, then he is to shave his head on the day of his purification. Seven days later he is to shave it again.
6.10: On the eighth day, he is to bring two turtledoves or two pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
6.11: Then the priest is to offer one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering to make atonement for him because of the guilt he incurred on account of his contact with the dead body. Then he is to consecrate his head on that day.
6.12: He is to dedicate to the Lord the days of his consecration by bringing a year old male lamb as his offering. The previous time will have failed because his consecration became defiled.
6.13: “This is the law of the Nazirite: When the days of his consecration are completed, he is to come to the entrance at the Tent of Meeting.
6.14: He is to bring an offering to the Lord, a year old male lamb, and a year old ewe female lamb, both without blemish, for a sin offering and a ram without blemish for a peace offering,
6.15: a basket of unleavened bread made from choice flour, cakes mixed with oil, a wafer of unleavened bread smeared with oil, along with grain and drink offerings.
6.16: The priest is to come into the Lord’s presence and present his sin and burnt offerings.
6.17: He is to offer the ram, a sacrifice of peace offering to the Lord, along with the basket of unleavened bread. Then the priest is to present his grain and drink offerings.
6.18: The Nazirite is then to shave his head of consecration at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. He is to take the lock of his head of consecration and set it over the fire where the peace offering for sacrifice is.
6.19: Then the priest is to take the boiled shoulder of the ram, one cake of unleavened bread from the basket, and one wafer of unleavened bread. He is to place them in the hands of the Nazirite, after he himself has shaved his symbol of consecration.
6.20: The priest is to wave the offerings, that is, the breast and the thigh offering in the Lord’s presence. Then the Nazirite may drink wine afterward.
6.21: This is to be the law of the Nazirite when he commits his offering to the Lord on account of his consecration, over and beyond what he owns alone plus whatever he can provide, based on the vow from his own mouth that he vows to fulfill on account of the law of his consecration.”
6.23: “Teach Aaron and his sons to bless the Israelis:
6.24:
May the Lord bless you
    and guard you.
6.25:
May the Lord’s face enlighten you
    and bestow favor on you.
6.26:
May the Lord turn to face you,
    lavishing peace on you!
6.27: They are to pour out my name to the Israelis while I continue to bless them.”

7.1: The same day that Moses finished setting up, anointing, and consecrating the tent and its utensils, he also anointed and consecrated the altar and its utensils.
7.2: Then the presiding leaders of Israel, as heads of the ancestral houses, brought an offering. They were the leaders of the tribes who supervised the census.
7.3: They brought their offering into the Lord’s presence, consisting of six covered carts and twelve oxen—one cart each from two leaders and an ox from each one. After they presented them in front of the tent,
7.5: “Take these gifts from them and use them in service at the Tent of Meeting. Present them to the descendants of Levi, distributing them to each person according to his work.”
7.6: So Moses took the carts and the oxen and presented them to the descendants of Levi.
7.7: Two carts and four oxen were given to the descendants of Gershon for their work.
7.8: Four carts and eight oxen were given to the descendants of Merari for their work.
7.9: But he gave none of them to the descendants of Kohath, because their responsibility was to carry the holy things on their shoulders.
7.10: The leaders brought the offerings for the dedication of the altar the same day that it was anointed. After the leaders brought their offering to the altar,

9.1: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Wilderness of Sinai during the first month of the second year that they had left Egypt,
9.2: “The Israelis are to observe the Passover at its appointed time
9.3: on the fourteenth day of this month. You are to observe it at this appointed time between the evenings. You are to observe it according to all its decrees and laws.”
9.4: So Moses instructed the Israelis to observe the Passover.
9.5: They observed the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month at twilight, in the Wilderness of Sinai. The Israelis did everything that the Lord had commanded through Moses.
9.6: But there were men who couldn’t observe the Passover that day because they had come in contact with a corpse. That very day, they approached Moses and Aaron
9.7: and asked, “Why can’t we bring an offering to the Lord at the appointed time among the Israelis, even though we are unclean because we came in contact with a corpse?”
9.8: “Wait while I hear what the Lord has to say about you,” Moses replied.
9.10: “Instruct the Israelis that when any of you or your descendants becomes unclean due to contact with a corpse, or if he is on a long journey, he nevertheless is to observe the Lord’s Passover.
9.11: On the fourteenth day of the second month at twilight, they are to eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
9.12: They are not to leave any of it to remain until morning nor are they to break any of its bones. They are to observe it according to all the statutes of the Passover.
9.13: Now as to the person who is clean and isn’t traveling, but fails to observe the Passover, that person is to be eliminated from his people, because he didn’t bring an offering to the Lord at its appointed time. That person is to bear his sin.
9.14: If a resident alien lives with you and wants to observe the Lord’s Passover, let him observe it according to the statutes and laws of the Passover. You are to maintain the same statute for the resident alien as you do for the native of the land.”
9.15: On the same morning that the tent was set up, a cloud covered the tent, that is, the Tent of Testimony, and in the evening fire appeared over the tent until morning.
9.16: It was so continuously—there was a cloud covering by day, and a fire cloud appeared at night.
9.17: Whenever the cloud above the tent ascended, the Israelis would travel and encamp in the place where the cloud settled.
9.18: According to whatever the Lord said, the Israelis would travel. According to whatever the Lord said, they would camp as long as the cloud remained over the Tent of Meeting.
9.19: When the cloud over the tent remained for a longer time, the Israelis did what the Lord had instructed and didn’t travel.
9.20: There were times when the cloud remained over the tent for a number of days. They camped in accordance with the Lord’s instructions and they traveled in accordance with the Lord’s instructions.
9.21: There were times when the cloud remained from evening until morning, but when the cloud ascended in the morning, they would journey. Whether by day or by night, they would travel whenever the cloud ascended.
9.22: Whether for two days, a month, or for longer periods, whenever the cloud would remain above the tent, the Israelis would remain in camp, not traveling. But whenever it ascended, then they would travel.
9.23: According to what the Lord said, they would remain in camp, and according to what the Lord said, they would travel. They kept the commands that the Lord had given through Moses.

11.1: Eventually, the people began complaining about their distress, and the Lord heard them. When the Lord heard, his anger flared up and the Lord’s fire incinerated some of them within the outskirts of the camp.
11.2: When the people cried out to Moses, he prayed to the Lord and the fire stopped.
11.3: He then named that place Taberah, because the Lord’s fire had incinerated some of them.
11.4: Meanwhile, certain riff-raff among the people had an insatiable appetite for food. As a result, they wept and turned back, and the Israelis cried out, “If only somebody would feed us some meat!
11.5: How we remember the fish that we used to eat in Egypt for free! And the cucumbers, melons, leeks, onions, and garlic!
11.6: But now we can’t stand it anymore, because there’s nothing in front of us except this manna.”
11.7: Now manna was reminiscent of coriander seed, with an appearance similar to amber.
11.8: People would go out to gather it, then they would grind it in mills or pound it in mortars, and then they would boil it in pots or make cakes out of it that tasted like butter cakes.
11.9: When the dew fell in the camp, the manna came with it.
11.10: Moses heard the people weeping throughout their entire families. Everyone gathered at the entrance to their tents so that the Lord was very angry. Moses thought the situation was bad,
11.11: so he asked the Lord, “Why did you bring all this trouble to your servant? Why haven’t I found favor in your eyes? After all, you’re putting the burden of this entire people on me!
11.12: Did I conceive this people or give birth to them, so that you would tell me to carry them near my heart like a wet nurse carries a suckling baby to the land that you promised to their forefathers?
11.13: Where am I going to get meat to give this people? After all, they’re crying in front of me, ‘Give us meat to eat!’
11.14: I cannot carry this whole nation! The burden is too heavy for me!
11.15: If this is how you treat me, please kill me right now, if I’ve found favor in your eyes, because I don’t want to keep staring at all of this misery!”
11.16: Then the Lord told Moses, “Gather together for me 70 men who are elders of Israel, men whom you know to be elders of the people and officers over them. Then bring them to the Tent of Meeting and let them stand there with you.
11.17: Then I’ll come down and speak with you. I’ll take some of the spirit that rests on you and apportion it among them, so that they may help you bear the burden of the people. That way, you won’t bear it by yourself.”
11.18: “But give this command to the people: ‘You are to consecrate yourselves, because tomorrow you’re going to eat meat, since you’ve complained where the Lord can hear it, “Who can give us meat to eat? After all, life was better with us in Egypt.” Therefore, the Lord is going to give you meat and you’ll eat—
11.19: not only for a day, or for two days, or for five days, or for ten days, or for 20 days,
11.20: but for a whole month—until it comes out your nostrils and makes you vomit. This is because you’ve despised the Lord, who is among you, and you cried out in his presence by complaining, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?”’”
11.21: Moses responded, “I’m with 600,000 people on foot and you’re saying I am to give them enough meat to eat for a whole month?
11.22: What if we were to slaughter our entire inventory of flocks and herds for them? Would that be enough? What if we could gather all the fish in the sea in nets for them? Would that be enough, either?”
11.23: But the Lord responded to Moses, “Is the Lord short on power? You’re now going to witness whether what I say will come to pass or not.”
11.24: So Moses went out and told the people what the Lord had said. He gathered 70 men from the elders of the people and stationed them around the tent.
11.25: The Lord came down in a cloud, spoke to Moses, and made an apportionment from the spirit who rested on him to the 70 elders. When the spirit rested on them, they prophesied, but that was it.
11.26: Now two men had remained in camp. One was named Eldad and the other was named Medad. When the spirit rested on them, since they were among those who were listed but had not gone out to the tent, they stayed behind and prophesied in the camp.
11.27: A young man ran and reported to Moses, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp!”
11.28: In response, Nun’s son Joshua, Moses’ attendant and one of his choice men, exclaimed, “My master Moses! Stop them!”
11.29: “Are you jealous on account of me?” Moses asked in reply. “I wish all of the Lord’s people were prophets and that the Lord would put his spirit upon them!”
11.30: Then Moses—that is, he and the elders of Israel—returned to the camp.
11.31: Just then, a wind burst forth from the Lord, who brought quails from the sea and spread them all around the camp, about a day’s journey in each direction, completely encircling the camp about two cubits deep on top of the ground!
11.32: The people stayed up all that day, all that night, and all through the next day, gathering quails. The one who gathered least gathered enough to fill ten omers, as they spread out all around the camp.
11.33: But even as they were chewing the meat and before they had swallowed it, the Lord became very angry with the people and struck them with a disastrous plague.
11.34: That’s why the place was named Kibroth-hattaavah, because they buried the people there who had an insatiable appetite for meat.
11.35: Later, the people left Kibroth-hattaavah for Hazeroth and camped there.

12.1: Miriam and Aaron rebelled against Moses on account of the Cushite woman that he had married.
12.2:
They asked, “Has the Lord spoken only through Moses? Hasn’t he also spoken through us?”
But the Lord heard it.
12.3: Now the man Moses was very humble—more than any person on earth.
12.4: All of a sudden, the Lord told Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, “The three of you are to come out to the Tent of Meeting.” So the three of them went out.
12.5: Then the Lord came down in a pillar of cloud, stood at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, and summoned Aaron and Miriam. So both of them went forward.
12.6: Then he told the two of them: “Pay attention to what I have to say! When there is a prophet among you, won’t I, the Lord, reveal myself to him in a vision? Won’t I speak with him in a dream?
12.7: But that’s not how it is with my servant Moses, since he has been entrusted with my entire household!
12.8: I speak to him audibly and in visions, not in mysteries. If he can gaze at the image of the Lord, why aren’t you afraid to speak against my servant Moses?”
12.9: Because the Lord was very angry with them, he left,
12.10: but when the cloud ascended from the tent, Miriam had become leprous, as white as snow! Aaron turned toward Miriam, and she had leprosy!
12.11: Aaron begged Moses, “I pray my lord, please don’t hold this sin against us, since we’ve acted foolishly and sinned in doing so.
12.12: Please don’t let her be like one of the living dead, who is born with a congenital skin disease.”
12.13: So Moses prayed to the Lord: “O Lord, please heal her.”
12.14: But the Lord told Moses, “If her father had merely spit in her face, wouldn’t she be humiliated? She is to be placed in isolation for seven days. After that, she may be brought in.”
12.15: So Miriam was isolated outside the camp for seven days and the people didn’t travel until Miriam was brought in.
12.16: After that, the people traveled from Hazeroth and encamped in the Wilderness of Paran.
